msDesc.head: Portable Ferial Psalter with Antiphons, Augustinian Use; Italy, Venice, 15th century, third quarter

msItem.title: Psalter, Augustinian Use
msItem.note: Fols. i and iv are paper fly-leaves, blank apart from modern notes. Fols. ii–iii are a folded paper strip attached to fol. iv with an 18th-century description of the manuscript (see ‘Provenance’). Fol. v is a parchment fly-leaf, blank apart from modern notes.

Augustinian calendar, laid out one month per page, written in red and black, approximately three-quarters full, with only some major feasts graded to ‘semiduplex’, ‘duplex’, ‘duplex minus’ and ‘duplex maius’. The feast of St Augustine is in red (28 August); his translation (28 February), ‘Conuersio sancti Augustini episcopi’ (5 May) and St Monica, his mother (4 May) are in red as festum duplex. Includes ‘Indulgentia ecclesie sancte Marie caritatis’ (4 April) and ‘consecratio altaris maioris et aliorum sex huius ecclesie caritatis’ (2 August) as festum duplex maius; and ‘Dedicatio ecclesie sancti marci’ as festum duplex (8 October). There are three feasts of St Mark (‘Sancti Marci euangeliste’, 25 April, in red as festum duplex; ‘Apparitio sancti marci euangeliste’, 25 June, in red; and ‘Translatio’, 31 January, in black). Other Venetian feasts include Hermagoras and Fortunatus (12 July), Magnus (6 October) and Justina of Padua (7 October). Contains Franciscan and Dominican saints: Peter of Verona (29 April), Dominic (5 August), Clare of Assisi (12 August), Francis (4 October) and Louis of Toulouse (19 August). Several saints have titles ‘canonicus regularis’. The months are headed by notes on their Hebrew and Greek names (apart from January), on the length of the solar and lunar month and on the number of hours in day and night. Verses on the ‘Egyptian’ days, which do not correspond to any of Hennig’s sets (1955), appear at the beginning and end of each month (apart from January, which lacks the verse at the beginning).
Two hymns for Matins on Sundays, with rubrics, followed by antiphons, ‘Primo dierum omnium ...’ (Chevalier, no. 15450); ‘Nocte surgentes uigilemus ...’ (Chevalier, no. 12035).

Psalms for Sunday Matins, Lauds, Little Hours, Vespers and Compline, followed by psalms for Matins, Lauds and Vespers during the week from Monday to Saturday in secular use, laid out as prose, without numbers, with titles ‘psalmus’ or ‘psalmus dauid’. Punctuated throughout with colon used to mark metrum and minor pauses, and punctus used to mark the ends of verses. The psalms are accompanied by antiphons, versicles, responses, etc. with rubrics. Subdivisions within psalms are not indicated, apart from psalm 118, subdivided into eleven 16-verse units. Psalms appointed to be recited first at Matins during the week in secular use (26, 38, 52, 68, 80 and 97) are marked with larger initials (see ‘Decoration’). Psalms, canticles, hymns, prayers and creeds are in the following order:

Hymnal (‘Incipit hymnarium per anni totius circulum’), containing hymns for the year from Advent to Pentecost, followed by the hymns for the feasts of the Trinity, Corpus Christi and saints, including Paul, Peter, Anthony of Padua (fols. 94v–95v), John the Baptist, Mary Magdalene and Francis (fols. 97v–98v). Conditor alme (Chevalier, no. 3733), Uerbum supernum prodiens a patre (Chevalier, no. 29391), Vox clara ecce intonat (Chevalier, no. 22199), Christe redemptor omnium ex patre (Chevalier, no. 2960), A solis ortu cardine (Chevalier, no. 26), Hostis herodes impie (Chevalier, no. 8073), Avdi benigne conditor (Chevalier, no. 1449), Ex more docti mis- tico (Chevalier, no. 5610), Iam christe sol iusticie (Chevalier, no. 8162), Urbs beata irusalem dicta pacis (Chevalier, no. 20918), Angularis fundamentum (Chevalier, no. 1082).

Litany, including Augustine (fourth) among ‘pontifices’, Francis, Antony of Padua and Dominic among ‘monaci et hermite’, and Clare among the virgins. Followed by collects (fol. 104r–v), some with rubrics ‘Oratio’:
(1) Deus cui proprium est misereri semper et parcere ...
(2) Exaudi quesumus domine supplicum preces ...
(3) Ineffabilem nobis domine misericordiam tuam ...
(4) Deus qui culpa offenderis ...
(5) Omnipotes sempiterne deus miserere famulo tuo ministro nostro ...
(6) Deus a quo sancta desideria ...
(7) Ure igne sancti spiritus renes nostros ...
(8) Fidelium deus omnium conditor et redemptor ...
(9) Actiones nostras quesumus domine aspirando preueni ...
(10) Omnipotens sempiterne deus qui uiuorum dominaris simul et mortuorum ... Fols. 105r–106v are ruled but blank; fols. 107–108 are paper fly-leaves.

supportDesc.foliation: modern, in pencil and ink; i–v + 1–108.
supportDesc.collation: (fols. i–v) fol. i is a paper fly-leaf conjoint with the upper pastedown; fols. ii–iii are a paper strip attached to fol. iv; fol. iv is a paper fly-leaf; fol. v is a parchment fly-leaf | (fols. 1–6) I (6) | (fols. 7–106) II–XI (10) | (fols. 107–108) fol. 107 is a paper fly-leaf; fol. 108 is a paper fly-leaf conjoint with the lower pastedown. Catchwords survive

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet for two columns, with single vertical bounding lines for each column extending the full height of page; 32 lines per page; written below the top line; written space: c. 100 68

handDesc.handNote: Formal Gothic book hand, black ink

decoDesc.decoNote: Red and blue penwork KL monograms in the calendar.

6-line Beatus-initial (fol. 7v), decorated with foliage, on gold background, infilled with profile bust of King David, looking up at rays of light, and border (upper, left and lower margins) decorated with filigree scrolls, flowers, foliage and gold discs.

5-line initial at the beginning of hymns (fol. 7r), decorated with foliage, on gold background, and border (upper, left and lower margins) made of gold and blue bars, decorated with filigree scrolls, flowers, foliage and gold discs.
5-line plain red or blue initials at liturgical divisions: psalms 26 (fol. 29r), 38 (fol. 38r), 52 (fol. 45v), 68 (fol. 53v), 80 (fol. 65r), 97 (fol. 75r).
5-line blue initial with red penwork at the beginning of the hymnal (fol. 87r).
2-line plain, alternating red and blue initials at the beginnings of psalms, canticles and hymns in the psalter.
2-line alternating red and blue initials, with contrasting penwork, at the beginnings of hymns in the hymnal, litany and collects.
1-line plain, alternating red and blue initials at the beginnings of verses and periods.

binding.p: Soranzo’s binding: parchment over pasteboard; small stiff flaps on the fore-edges of the covers. ‘155’ written in black ink on spine. Brown leather label on spine, framed by a gilt border, with gilt lettering ‘PSALT. || ET || HYMN. || COD . M.’. Sewn on four cords. Pastedowns and fly-leaves of paper with burgundy, purple and yellow floral designs (carta bassanese); further fly-leaves of 18th-century laid paper (no watermarks).

history.provenance: Made for Sancta Maria della Carità, Venice, monastery of the Lateran Canons: evidence of the calendar.
Jacopo Soranzo (1686–1761): binding. After Soranzo’s death by about 1780 at Cá Cornèr at San Maurizio, Venice (Mitchell, 1969).
Matteo Luigi Canonici of Venice (1727–c. 1806): bought soon after 1780.

A description of the manuscript on fols. ii–iii (a strip of paper attached with an 18th-century wafer seal) in an Italian, 18th-century (?) hand, but not the hand of Canonici or any of the earlier owners and librarians whose handwriting is illustrated in Mitchell (1969). Similar descriptions in the same hand are also found in MS. Canon. Bibl. Lat. 42, MS. Canon. Bibl. Lat. 85, MS. Canon. Pat. Lat. 88, MS. Add. D. 47, MS. Canon. Liturg. 105, MS. Canon. Liturg. 377 and MS. Canon. Liturg. 393: ‘Officium Feriale eccles. memb. in 8. saec. circ. xiv. cum Calend. integro, Hymnario pro Tempore, et orationes diversae, ac Litanae SS’.
history.acquisition: Bodleian Library: bought in 1817 from Canonici’s nephew Giovanni Perissinotti. Former shelfmark: ‘E codd. Bodl. Miscell. Liturg 155’ (fol. v verso).

recordHist.source: Elizabeth Solopova, Latin Liturgical Psalters in the Bodleian Library: A Select Catalogue (Oxford, 2013), pp. 538–44. Previously described in the Summary Catalogue. Summary Catalogue, vol. 4, p. 348

listBibl.head: Select bibliography to 2003:
listBibl.bibl: S. J. P. van Dijk, Latin Liturgical Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library, Oxford, vol. 2: Office Books (typescript, 1957), p. 105
Schaller, D. and Könsgen, E., Initia carminum Latinorum saeculo undecimo antiquiorum (Göttingen: Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht, 1977).

Dondi, C., ‘Books of hours: the development of the texts in printed form’ in K. Jensen (ed.), Incunabula and their readers: printing, selling and using books in the fifteenth century (London: British Library, 2003), pp. 53–70.
